SpNote.note:
CONTENTS
This library contains bright G stars accessible to UKIRT, between 3rd and 7th magnitude in the V band. CGS4 components are set up to do 2.2 micron spectroscopy with the 40 l/mm grating in first order. A standard nod of 11.74 arcseconds is used to place the star on the default rows.
USING THE LIBRARY
To use this library, identify (from the object name, which includes the RA and Dec) the star you want to observe, and drag it from the library window into your science programme.
You will need to drag a "flat and arc" sequence from the UKIRT templates library.
CAVEATS
Make sure that you set wavelengths identically in the flat/arc as in the standard star observation, and click the "default" buttons in the flat/arc to get the correct exposure time and black body settings.
AUTHOR: A J Adamson, JAC August 2000
SpNote.title: About this Library

SpNote.note:
This observation is flagged as a standard star. ORAC-DR uses this information to identify standards.
If you want to turn the flag off move the yellow highlight to the "standard star" line above and click on the "flag as standard" box.
SpNote.title: usage

SpNote.note:
enter your standard star (or target) co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step by step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
IF YOU WANT TO SELECT YOUR STANDARD STAR BY HAVING THE TSS SEARCH WITH THE TELESCOPE "NEARSTAR" IN REAL TIME THEN ENTER YOUR TARGET CO-ORDINATES HERE, AND DO NOT SPECIFY A GUIDE STAR. AFTER THESE ARE SENT TO THE TELESCOPE THERE WILL BE A PAUSE FOR THE TSS TO SLEW TO THE CHOSEN NEARBY STAR.
SpNote.title: standard coordinates information

SpNote.note:
For detailed advice about CGS4 see the web page at www.jach.hawaii.edu/UKIRT/instruments/cgs4/cgs4.html
Enter your desired CGS4 setup into the component below. Make sure you choose the same settings for grating, wavelength, order, slit width and position angle for your STANDARD STAR as for your sources.
Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range 7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note: The data reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data reduction recipe for speed. (this is a good idea if your exposure time short).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the quads more than once on your standard star , use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: set the number of repeats

SpNote.note:
this nods 20 rows along the slit
Offsets are enetered in the co-ordinate frame of the slit
p = along the slit q = perpendicular to the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

enter your standard star (or target) co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step by step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
IF YOU WANT TO SELECT YOUR STANDARD STAR BY HAVING THE TSS SEARCH WITH THE TELESCOPE "NEARSTAR" IN REAL TIME THEN ENTER YOUR TARGET CO-ORDINATES HERE, AND DO NOT SPECIFY A GUIDE STAR. AFTER THESE ARE SENT TO THE TELESCOPE THERE WILL BE A PAUSE FOR THE TSS TO SLEW TO THE CHOSEN NEARBY STAR.
SpNote.title: standard coordinates information

SpNote.note:
For detailed advice about CGS4 see the web page at www.jach.hawaii.edu/UKIRT/instruments/cgs4/cgs4.html
Enter your desired CGS4 setup into the component below. Make sure you choose the same settings for grating, wavelength, order, slit width and position angle for your STANDARD STAR as for your sources.
Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range 7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note: The data reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data reduction recipe for speed. (this is a good idea if your exposure time short).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the quads more than once on your standard star , use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: set the number of repeats

SpNote.note:
this nods 20 rows along the slit
Offsets are enetered in the co-ordinate frame of the slit
p = along the slit q = perpendicular to the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This observation is flagged as a standard star. ORAC-DR uses this information to identify standards.
If you want to turn the flag off move the yellow highlight to the "standard star" line above and click on the "flag as standard" box.

Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range 7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note: The data reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data reduction recipe for speed. (this is a good idea if your exposure time short).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the quads more than once on your standard star , use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: set the number of repeats

SpNote.note:
this nods 20 rows along the slit
Offsets are enetered in the co-ordinate frame of the slit
p = along the slit q = perpendicular to the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This observation is flagged as a standard star. ORAC-DR uses this information to identify standards.
If you want to turn the flag off move the yellow highlight to the "standard star" line above and click on the "flag as standard" box.
SpNote.title: usage

SpNote.note:
enter your standard star (or target) co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step by step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
IF YOU WANT TO SELECT YOUR STANDARD STAR BY HAVING THE TSS SEARCH WITH THE TELESCOPE "NEARSTAR" IN REAL TIME THEN ENTER YOUR TARGET CO-ORDINATES HERE, AND DO NOT SPECIFY A GUIDE STAR. AFTER THESE ARE SENT TO THE TELESCOPE THERE WILL BE A PAUSE FOR THE TSS TO SLEW TO THE CHOSEN NEARBY STAR.
SpNote.title: standard coordinates information

Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note: The data reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data reduction recipe for speed. (this is a good idea if your exposure time short).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the quads more than once on your standard star , use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: set the number of repeats

SpNote.note:
this nods 20 rows along the slit
Offsets are enetered in the co-ordinate frame of the slit
p = along the slit q = perpendicular to the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This observation is flagged as a standard star. ORAC-DR uses this information to identify standards.
If you want to turn the flag off move the yellow highlight to the "standard star" line above and click on the "flag as standard" box.
SpNote.title: usage

SpNote.note:
enter your standard star (or target) co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step by step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".

This observation is flagged as a standard star. ORAC-DR uses this information to identify standards.
If you want to turn the flag off move the yellow highlight to the "standard star" line above and click on the "flag as standard" box.
SpNote.title: usage

SpNote.note:
enter your standard star (or target) co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step by step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
IF YOU WANT TO SELECT YOUR STANDARD STAR BY HAVING THE TSS SEARCH WITH THE TELESCOPE "NEARSTAR" IN REAL TIME THEN ENTER YOUR TARGET CO-ORDINATES HERE, AND DO NOT SPECIFY A GUIDE STAR. AFTER THESE ARE SENT TO THE TELESCOPE THERE WILL BE A PAUSE FOR THE TSS TO SLEW TO THE CHOSEN NEARBY STAR.
SpNote.title: standard coordinates information

SpNote.note:
For detailed advice about CGS4 see the web page at www.jach.hawaii.edu/UKIRT/instruments/cgs4/cgs4.html
Enter your desired CGS4 setup into the component below. Make sure you choose the same settings for grating, wavelength, order, slit width and position angle for your STANDARD STAR as for your sources.
Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range 7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note: The data reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data reduction recipe for speed. (this is a good idea if your exposure time short).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the quads more than once on your standard star , use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: set the number of repeats

SpNote.note:
this nods 20 rows along the slit
Offsets are enetered in the co-ordinate frame of the slit
p = along the slit q = perpendicular to the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:

For detailed advice about CGS4 see the web page at www.jach.hawaii.edu/UKIRT/instruments/cgs4/cgs4.html
Enter your desired CGS4 setup into the component below. Make sure you choose the same settings for grating, wavelength, order, slit width and position angle for your STANDARD STAR as for your sources.
Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range 7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note: The data reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data reduction recipe for speed. (this is a good idea if your exposure time short).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the quads more than once on your standard star , use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: set the number of repeats

SpNote.note:
this nods 20 rows along the slit
Offsets are enetered in the co-ordinate frame of the slit
p = along the slit q = perpendicular to the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This observation is flagged as a standard star. ORAC-DR uses this information to identify standards.
If you want to turn the flag off move the yellow highlight to the "standard star" line above and click on the "flag as standard" box.
SpNote.title: usage

SpNote.note:
enter your standard star (or target) co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step by step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
IF YOU WANT TO SELECT YOUR STANDARD STAR BY HAVING THE TSS SEARCH WITH THE TELESCOPE "NEARSTAR" IN REAL TIME THEN ENTER YOUR TARGET CO-ORDINATES HERE, AND DO NOT SPECIFY A GUIDE STAR. AFTER THESE ARE SENT TO THE TELESCOPE THERE WILL BE A PAUSE FOR THE TSS TO SLEW TO THE CHOSEN NEARBY STAR.

Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note: The data reduction recipe specified below uses the most basic data reduction recipe for speed. (this is a good idea if your exposure time short).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: To repeat the quads more than once on your standard star , use the repeat item below to specify how many times you want to repeat it.
SpNote.title: set the number of repeats

SpNote.note:
this nods 20 rows along the slit
Offsets are enetered in the co-ordinate frame of the slit
p = along the slit q = perpendicular to the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This observation is flagged as a standard star. ORAC-DR uses this information to identify standards.
If you want to turn the flag off move the yellow highlight to the "standard star" line above and click on the "flag as standard" box.
SpNote.title: usage

SpNote.note:
enter your standard star (or target) co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step by step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
IF YOU WANT TO SELECT YOUR STANDARD STAR BY HAVING THE TSS SEARCH WITH THE TELESCOPE "NEARSTAR" IN REAL TIME THEN ENTER YOUR TARGET CO-ORDINATES HERE, AND DO NOT SPECIFY A GUIDE STAR. AFTER THESE ARE SENT TO THE TELESCOPE THERE WILL BE A PAUSE FOR THE TSS TO SLEW TO THE CHOSEN NEARBY STAR.
